data.title: Respect ATOM_HOME env var for portability
data.body:
This PR unifies all references to use the `ATOM_HOME` environment variable as the location to store packages, compile caches, node headers, etc.

The location still defaults to `~/.atom` when unset.

This should make Atom portable meaning it will write no files outside this location.

Closes #2939

data.title: incorrect line ending
data.body:
When I updated to 0.177.0, line endings are incorrectly represented:

![screen shot 2015-02-03 at 17 04 49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/59380/6030640/dee826aa-abc6-11e4-81aa-ed566decd461.png)

data.title: fs.existsSync() is deprecated. Use fs.accessSync() instead.

Hey there,

The package atom-ternjs i'm working on, keeps throwing this error.
I checked twice and there are no calls to fs.existsSync() anymore.

Does this error also effects dependencies, that make use of it?

Greeting from Berlin
tststs

data.title: Add asar support in Atom
data.body:
By using [asar](https://github.com/atom/asar) to [package the `app` folder](https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/blob/master/docs/tutorial/application-packaging.md) into a single file,  we should be able to speed up the install time and startup time on computers that run on HDD significantly.

Known issues:
- [x] `index.js` not loading on Windows.
- [x] Can not interpret Less stylesheets because of graceful-fs not compatible with `asar`.
- [x] Program not quitting on Windows.
- [x] Tasks not working.
- [x] `apm` and `atom` commands can not be installed.
- [x] `apm` can not show built-in packages.

data.title: opening the Developer Tools pane prevents the Command Palette from taking focus
data.body:
If I use the keyboard to open the developer tool panel (using the command palette) and then try to run another command using the command palette, I end up typing into the console. In detail:
- make sure the developer tool panel is closed
- type cmd-shift-p to open the command palette
- type "toggle dev" followed by a "return" to open the developer tool pane
- type cmd-shift-p to open the command palette again
- type anything; the text goes into the console (developer tool pane) at the prompt, instead of into the command palette. This is scary. I expected the text to go into the command palette.

By contrast, if I type cmd-t (to open the file palette) after I open the developer tool pane, nothing seems to happen. I don't get the file palette, but at least I don't end up typing somewhere unexpected and possibly dangerous.

Personally I wish cmd-t and cmd-ctrl-p both worked normally at that point. However, I admit that I am not an atom developer; I only open the developer panel when I want to see error messages. If I was a heavy atom developer I might prefer the cmd-t behavior. I can't imagine ever wanting the cmd-ctrl-p behavior.

I am on MacOS 10.9.5 with Atom 0.177.0

data.title: package dependency npm install failure

Running Atom Version 0.176.0 (0.176.0) and atom-fixmyjs 1.3.0
Originally from sindresorhus/atom-fixmyjs/issues/7

Reproduceable. This appears to be an atom bug, rather than in the atom-fixmyjs package. It looks like there is an npm install error where the fixmyjs dependency doesn't get installed. Previous versions of Atom worked fine, and there were no relevant changes in atom-fixmyjs.

If I go to ~/.atom/packages/fixmyjs and run npm install it works, but with a clean install without manually installing the dependency, if I go to the command palette I can execute FixMyJS the web developer view will show this:

data.title: Add section on "composed" commands to Advanced Keymap document
data.body:
This is intended to address the commonly-asked question about making a keybinding execute multiple commands.

It also updates the example code for a command by removing the reference to the deprecated `EditorView` and just using the example from the `CommandRegistry` documentation.

data.title: Built-in documentation?
data.body:
Many editors have built-in documentation. For example, the `C-h` prefix in Emacs, `:help` in Vim, and `^G` in nano. Moreover, many of them also include a tutorial for new users (`:!vimtutor` in Vim and `help-with-tutorial` in Emacs, for example). But for Atom, I only found the `welcome` package.

Is there any plan for built-in documentation in Atom?

data.title: Atom on Chromebook?
data.body: Have you talked about bringing Atom to the world of Chromebooks as a packaged app or something? Any thoughts on that?

data.title: Fix link to wrong version of Jasmine
data.body:
Applies to #5354 

Accidentally pushed this change originally to a different pull request after that PR had been merged. Making a new PR just for this change now :grinning:

data.title: Some suggestions to CONTRIBUTING.md
data.body:
I have a few suggestions to CONTRIBUTING.md. Here are some items that can be added:
- A brief introduction to the workflow (or at least link to help.github.com)
- Web QA (find problems of atom.io across a variety of platforms and browsers)
- Atom QA (find bugs in Atom, Atom Shell, apm, and official Atom packages)
- Translation (I'm not sure whether/when Atom and/or atom.io will support languages other than English, though)
- Something like Mozilla's "Good First Bugs" and "Mentored Bugs"
- Contribute to Atom Wiki, perhaps. (See https://discuss.atom.io/t/a-multilingual-wiki-for-atom/14640)

Also, coding opportunities can be classified to languages/technologies. For example:
- CoffeeScript/JavaScript (Atom and its core packages)
- C++ (Atom Shell)
- Node.js
- CSS/Less (syntax/UI themes)
- Jasmine (spec)
- HTML
- Shell script (e.g., some scripts in `script/`, `atom.sh`, package CI scripts etc.)

data.title: Need cross-platform support in Getting Started doc
data.body:
Can the doc owner find-and-replace Mac-only "cmd" keyboard shortcuts with the idiomatic cross-platform "ctrl/cmd"?

A lot of people won't actually know to translate cmd to ctrl. People at the beginning of their software journeys, so to speak, e.g. 12- or 18-year-olds who have only ever used Windows or Linux. And vast numbers of people in developing countries who have never been in the same room with a Mac, and again especially at the beginning of their journeys/careers, before they've encountered a lot of content that features "cmd".

data.title: Updated doc to specify package language
data.body:
I just added a sentence in the first paragraph: "You can write a package in Javascript or CoffeeScript."

This doesn't seem to be declared anywhere. We can apparently write packages in JS but the word 'Javascript' is nowhere in the doc. index.coffee would presumably imply to readers that packages are written in CoffeeScript, but this should be stated explicitly, and early. (And the JS option will be hugely important to many.)

data.title: ctrl + right doesn't wrap around lines that have CR LF line endings
data.body:
In both tests the ctrl key is held down and the right arrow key is pressed twice.

![ctrl_right_atom_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8430611/6011041/cba690f2-ab05-11e4-882e-3b2faba7447f.gif)

data.title: Javascript comment indentation
data.body:
When auto indenting JS comment blocks, 

```js
/**
 *
 */
```

becomes:

```js
/**
*
*/
```

Since the first version is a pretty common comment block pattern (used in JSDoc and YUIDoc and similar projects), it'd be great if the auto indent feature could support this indentation instead of messing with it.

data.title: Causing Itunes crackle
data.body:
So a weird problem. But I pinpointed it to when Atom is open and I'm playing music on Itunes, I get a popping/crackling sound from my music.

I've never noticed it before but for some reason it started this morning, and the only package I got inbetween last time I played music while using atom was terminal-status.

data.title: Smooth scrolling (Linux)
data.body:
I've seen some work in improving the smoothness of scrolling so far. But I'm wondering if it's actually possible to get real smooth scrolling or at least if it's planned for the near future?
Just reducing the scroll sensitivity to 1 line at a time is not a real solution...

data.title: sort items in File Finder / Buffer Finder in recent used order
data.body:
The initial order in Buffer Finder is recent used order, it is ok, but when I enter some characters to filter it, it tunes to alphabetical order :(

In File Finder, when I filter it, it then show many files I never edit it at top of this list.

In my previous editor Sublimetext, it saves file edit order info to workspace file and use this list to sort finder items.

data.title: Multi commands for keybinding
data.body:
Hi,

if I understand correctly the documentation (https://atom.io/docs/latest/advanced/keymaps) tells me that it is possible to use such keybindings like this:

```
'shift-enter': 'editor:move-to-end-of-line editor:newline'
```

But this doesn't work. Don't know if this is just a misunderstanding or just a feature-request :D
I use version 0.176.0 26.1.2015 22:59:35 under Win7

Kind Regards
Ruben

data.title: Saving to readonly file - Uncaught Error: EPERM, operation not permitted foo.txt
data.body:
### Repro
1. Edit a readonly file
2. Save
### Result

Atom hangs for a while and eventually an uncaught exception (propergates)
### Desired

Atom should report "cannot save readonly file, save under different file name?" or something to that effect.
### Info

**Atom Version**: 0.166.0
**System**: Microsoft Windows 7 Professional 
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: EPERM, operation not permitted 'c:\Users\josh.gerrard\foo.txt

```
At c:\Users\josh.gerrard\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.166.0\resources\app\src\workspace.js:622

Error: EPERM, operation not permitted 'c:\Users\josh.gerrard\foo.txt
  at Error (native)
  at Object.fs.openSync (fs.js:455:18)

  at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.save (c:\Users\josh.gerrard\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.166.0\resources\app\node_modules\text-buffer\lib\text-buffer.js:954:19)
  at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.save (c:\Users\josh.gerrard\AppData\Local\atom\app-0.166.0\resources\app\src\text-editor.js:589:26)
```
